div.head: TO THE FREEMEN OF THE STATE of SOUTH-CAROLINA.

div.p: THE proceedings of the late A≈ø≈øembly held at Jack≈øonborough have already excited the attention not only of this, but of other States; and ≈øome of the laws then enacted are of ≈øo ≈øerious a nature, that the memory of them will la≈øt, and their con≈øequences operate, when the authors of the mea≈øures ≈øhall be no more. By one of tho≈øe laws, upwards of two hundred men who had been citizens of this State before the reduction of Charle≈øtown, have been ≈øtript of all their property: innocent wives and children involved in the calamity of hu≈øbands and fathers, their widows are deprived of the right of dower, their children di≈øinherited, and them≈øelves bani≈øhed for ever from this country. And this without proce≈øs, trial, examination, or hearing; and without allowing them the ≈øacred right of proving their innocence on a future day. Under other acts of that a≈ø≈øembly, a number of the inhabitants are ≈øubjected to heavy fines, ≈øome to near one third, others to one eight, and ≈øome to a tenth part of their e≈øtate, real and per≈øonal, without better proof of crime than report and ≈øugge≈øtions. Another act excludes from the freedom of voting or being elected to a ≈øeat in the legi≈ølature, almo≈øt a majority of our citizens. The crimes of all con≈øi≈øt in the part which they were ≈øaid to have taken after the reduction of South-Carolina by the Briti≈øh army.

One would imagine there is no free country upon earth, in which laws bringing ≈øuch ruin on ≈øo many families, and ≈øo big with political mi≈øchief, would not have been publickly di≈øcu≈ø≈øed before this day. with a ≈øen≈øe of his own danger; or that the fear of the Governor's extraordinary power, awes men into ≈øilence; or that they are indifferent about public affairs; not a man has yet undertaken to enquire into the ju≈øtice or inju≈øtice of it, or a≈øk his neighbour how far the Legi≈ølature could effect the ruin and di≈øgrace of ≈øo many of his fellow citizens, con≈øi≈øtently with the laws, con≈øtitution, and happine≈øs of his country.

From every point of view in which I con≈øider tho≈øe proceedings, I am convinced it is e≈ø≈øential to the future peace and liberty of our country, that a true judgment be formed on the matter. The people at large in whom the ≈øovereignty of the State ≈øhould be ve≈øted, ought to be informed whether public mea≈øures be right or wrong; and it therefore becomes the duty of every citizen to pre≈øent the ≈øubject in as open and publick a light as opportunity or knowledge may enable him. Under this per≈øua≈øion I venture to offer a few remarks to the con≈øideration of the publick; and I only wi≈øh my talents were equal to the importance of the ≈øubject. I tru≈øt the candid, plain manner in which I ≈øhall di≈øcour≈øe on it will an≈øwer for me, that I have no other de≈øign by it but what has been the object of my pur≈øuit through ≈øeven years public ≈øervice; that is, the liberty and peace of my courtry.

I mu≈øt fir≈øt ob≈øerve, that G‚Äîr R‚Äî's proclamation of the 27th of September 1781, was the fountain from whence ≈øprung ≈øome of tho≈øe bitter laws, and the forfeitures and di≈øabilities abovementioned. div.head: I. On the Citizens making a temporary Submi≈ø≈øion to the Briti≈øh Arms, after the reduction of Charle≈øtown in 1780.
div.p: THIS State, ≈øoon after the reduction of Charle≈øtown, may be ≈øtrictly ≈øaid to have been conquered. Not only the capital, but every po≈øt throughout the country was in the hands of the enemy. The Governor who repre≈øented the Sovereignty of the State, had provided for his ≈øafety by flight, and all the Continental troops in South-Carolina were either killed, taken, or routed.

The enemy, thus ma≈øters of the country, re≈øolved to reduce by military force the inhabitants to obedience. And Sir Henry Clinton accordingly in the month of June 1781, i≈ø≈øues a proclamation, Commanding all per≈øons whatever inhabitants of this province, (tho≈øe who were in Charle≈øtown and Fort Moultrie at the time of their capitulations and ≈øurrender, or were then in actual confinement excepted) who ≈øhall after the 20th of June next, neglect to return to his allegiance and to his Maje≈øty's government, will be con≈øidered as enemies and rebels to the ≈øame, and treated accordingly.

Thus a military de≈øpoti≈øm was e≈øtabli≈øhed throughout the ≈øettlements, and to compleat this mi≈øerable ≈øcene of woes, the army under General Gates, and a divi≈øion under General Sumpter, to whom we looked up as our deliverers, were entirely defeated. The country thus abandoned to a cruel, unprincipled foe, the people had no idea but that our independence was lo≈øt irrecoverably. And indeed the advantages gained by the enemy were ≈øo rapid and deci≈øive, it was for ≈øome time apprehended thro' the other States, and even by many members of Congre≈øs, that Carolina and Georgia mu≈øt in the end revert to the domination of Great Britain.

In this ≈øituation nece≈ø≈øity, who≈øe dominion triumphs over all human laws pointed out to our inhabitants, that as there was neither government, laws, nor army to protect them, they were at liberty to protect them≈øelves, as well as they could. This is the law of Nature and of Nations: And all State≈ømen, the be≈øt lawyers, and mo≈øt eminent writers, agree, that when an invader over-runs a country, defeats the ≈øtanding forces, and ≈øubverts its government, the inhabitants of ≈øuch a country are ju≈øtifiable to take the conqueror's protection and obey his laws; and whether the government be a monarchy or republick, it makes no difference, as the rea≈øon of the thing is the ≈øame.

In Germany and other parts of Europe, it is not uncommon for one and the ≈øame city to be taken and retaken and have different ma≈øters in one campaign. And the inhabitants of ≈øuch a city, magi≈øtrates and all, who are not ≈øoldiers by profe≈ø≈øion, uniformly take an oath of allegiance to the ≈øtronger ≈øide, which oath is binding only ≈øo long as the conqueror's power la≈øts. I ≈øhall bring forward the authority of the be≈øt writers on the laws of nations and nature to prove that taking protection from a conqueror is no crime.

Lib. 8. c. 11. In ≈øupport of this right he quotes the ca≈øe of the Petilini from Livy. This nation being in alliance with the Romans, and pre≈ø≈øed by their enemies, ≈øent for a≈ø≈øi≈øtance. This part of my ≈øubject I ≈øhall conclude with a quotation from Mr. Heboes, a writer who≈øe authority is the more to be depended on, as be lived in England in the time of the grand rebellion, when England then was, as Carolina was lately, di≈øtracted by a fierce war, and were per≈øecuting each other, as the parliament forces, or tho≈øe of the king got the better.

p.q:
Becau≈øe I find, ≈øays Hobbes, by our Engli≈øh books lately printed, that the civil wars have not ≈øufficiently taught men in which point of time it is that a ≈øubject becomes obliged to the conqueror, nor how it comes about that men are obliged to obey his laws. that of an ordinary ≈øubject, (that is not a ≈øoldier by profe≈ø≈øion) it is then when the means of life are within the guards and garri≈øons of the enemy: for it is then he hath no longer protection from his ≈øovereign, but is protected by the adver≈øe party for his contribution. The ≈øovereignty is the ≈øoul of the commonwealth, which once departed from the body, the members do no more receive their motion from it. The end of obedience is protection, which where≈øoever a man ≈øeeketh, either in his own, or his enemy's ≈øword, nature applieth his obedience to it. Nothing can be clearer than this doctrine; and however ≈øhocking it will ≈øeem to tho≈øe who have kept a perpetual boa≈øting of their own virtue and clamour again≈øt ≈øuch as the Briti≈øh did not think fit to ≈øend to St. Augu≈øtine; yet this is what is good law in South-Carolina as well as all the world over: All tho≈øe writers who≈øe authority we rely on in law-matters laying it down for law, that ≈øubjects are excu≈øed and ju≈øtified, and not liable to be impleaded or called to account for taking protection from a conqueror or u≈øurper.

I hope I have ≈øaid enough to ≈øatisfy the reader, that our inhabitants did nothing more than their duty in taking protection: and if they thought they could ≈øecure better treatment, or alleviate their calamity by congratulations, they had an undoubted right to do it. It did not ≈øhew much political wi≈ødom, I allow; but let that matter be as it will, they did not commit any crime again≈øt the laws or government, for neither law nor government exi≈øted. The Sovereign power was in a ≈øtate of temporary death, the ≈øoul was fled and departed, and nothing remained but the carca≈øe; which could no more be injured or violated by any of our former
citizens taking protection, or ≈øigning a congratulation, than they could be ≈øaid to commit murder by trampling on the body of a man who had been dead and buried many months.

With re≈øpect to pre≈øenting congratulations, it were ea≈øy to prove from what happened in other countries that they are by no means a true te≈øt or proof of the public ≈øentiments, or of tho≈øe who pre≈øent them. Such addre≈ø≈øes are obtained in all countries by a few de≈øigning men, and the re≈øt by threats, terror, or a ≈øort of impul≈øe, follow the example. So little, ≈øays Burnet, do the≈øe appearances ≈øignify. This levity, this infirmity of the multitude, no ≈øtate≈øman before our time thought in earne≈øt of puni≈øhing. Our laws cannot do it. I well know prudent men, or rather ≈øuch as think them≈øelves ≈øo, will ≈øay, that this doctrine of Protection ought not to be drawn into di≈øcu≈ø≈øion, but ≈øhould ≈øleep in ≈øilence for the pre≈øent. Has not the government been ≈øeized, and its con≈øtitution ≈øubverted, by the few in con≈øequence of that doctrine? For men in power to per≈øuade the people, that they committed crimes and acted di≈øhonourably, when there is neither crime nor di≈øhonour in the ca≈øe, is a mo≈øt mi≈øchievous policy. It breaks that ≈øpirit, and generous pride, which is the be≈øt guardian of publick liberty and private honour. It overwhelms the publick as well as the private mind, with con≈øcious inferiority; degrades men in their own opinion, and tenders them fit tools for the ambitious de≈øigns, and arbitrary di≈øpo≈øitions of haughty a≈øpiring ≈øuperiors.

The citizens who came from Charle≈øtown in the ≈øcorching hearts of Augu≈øt la≈øt, by a proclamation, afforded a melancholy

Having proved the taking protection was no crime in the people, I ≈øhall go on to ≈øhew, that on the re≈øtoration of the republic and laws from Briti≈øh thraldom, the protection-men who had been our citizens before, were as fully entitled to all the rights and freedom of citizen≈øhip, as tho≈øe who were detained pri≈øoners of war, or took refuge to the northward.

And this is not only agreeable to ju≈øtice, but the freedom and liberty of the country would be de≈øtroyed if it were otherwi≈øe. If in a republic a few could ≈øet up preten≈øions to ≈øuperior political merit, over the whole aggregate body of the people, and deprive the latter of their rights and privileges, this would be nothing more nor le≈øs than overthrowing the con≈øtitution, ≈øeizing on the liberties of the people, and ≈øetting up an arbitrary government of the few The laws of nations as well as the rights of nature therefore dictate, that when a country oppre≈ø≈øed by a foreign power regains its liberty, the citizens ≈øhould be re≈øtored to all the rights and liberties they before enjoyed.

p.q: A whole nation, ≈øays Puffendorf, cap. 6, when it hath, either by its own ≈øtrength, or the a≈ø≈øi≈øtance of friends or allies, ≈øhaken off an enemy's yoke, recovers its liberty and antient ≈øtate. div.p:
This authority goes to the point; but in order to make it plainer, I ≈øhall put a ca≈øe: I ≈øhall ≈øuppo≈øe a nation governed by a limited monarch, invaded by a powerful enemy, and after trying the fortune of war, entirely vanqui≈øhed. In ca≈øe this country be again recovered by the a≈ø≈øi≈øtance of friends or allies, would it not be ≈øtrange indeed, that the prince on returning, ≈øhould call the conque≈øt over his people, and their nece≈ø≈øity to ≈øubmit, by the name of trea≈øon again≈øt the government? Should he carry this notion ≈øo far as to exclude the ≈øubjects from the benefit of the antient laws, and deny to all the rights of citizen≈øhip, except to his friends or adherents, and ≈øuch who≈øe captivity prevented them from following the example of the re≈øt, or who≈øe re≈øidence on the frontier afforded an ea≈øy removal into another country; would not this procedure be con≈øidered as ≈øeizing the government and ≈øetting up his own will to reign in≈øtead of laws? If there was a ≈øpark of freedom left in ≈øuch a
country, they would a≈øk what his de≈øign and pre≈øence for proclaiming to the world that his ≈øubjects had committed trea≈øon, and forfeited, without trial or conviction, the rights and protection of the antient laws? To cut this matter ≈øhort, was not this exactly the cour≈øe taken by the late G‚Äî R‚Äî, who acted only as mini≈øter of State for our Republic? Did he not i≈ø≈øue his proclamation to make the people and the nations around believe, that by a temporary ≈øubmi≈ø≈øion to a conqueror who had the power of life and death in his hands, they had incurred crime and di≈øhonour? div.head: II. On Governor Rutledge's Proclamation of the 27th of September, 1781.
div.p: A Mea≈øure ≈øo ≈øingular as this is mu≈øt be produced by ≈øome uncommon motive. It is, however, one of tho≈øe things, which the more a man will think of, the more will he dete≈øt it. For it is calculated for no other end but to ≈øow the poi≈øonous ≈øeeds of faction and party, to di≈øgrace the middling and lower cla≈øs of our citizens, and throw the whole weight and powers of government out of the people into a few families. G‚Äîr R‚Äî's proclamation, and the plans which he carried la≈øt a≈ø≈øembly, would, unle≈øs unrivetted by a future one, fa≈øten at one blow in this country, a fierce and jealous ari≈øtocracy, which has been gaining ground for ≈øeven years pa≈øt. Mi≈øerable is that republic who≈øe citizens want di≈øcernment to penetrate through ≈øuch de≈øigns, or are afraid to expo≈øe them!

For ≈øome time before the battle of the Eutaw Springs, almo≈øt all our citizens without the lines of Charle≈øtown, and with few exceptions, all within, worried by the tyranny of the Briti≈øh army, held them and their cau≈øe in the utmo≈øt dete≈øtation. The victory obtained in that action proved a death-warrant to the tory intere≈øt in this State; and the capture of the Briti≈øh army under Lord Cornwallis following on the heels of the event, rou≈øed the few tories there were as from a dream; and they ≈øaw clearly they had hitherto only deluded them≈øelves in thinking this country would be conquered. And tho≈øe who from zeal, levity, or nece≈ø≈øity, adhered to the enemy after the fall of Charle≈øtown, employed all the means in their power to pave the way to a reconciliation. This was not difficult for tho≈øe who had not per≈øonal enemies among us; for General Greene wanted ≈øupplies, the town abounded with merchandize,
of which our old citizens found means to ≈øend out large quantities. The very adventurers who followed the Briti≈øh army to South-Carolina became our friends, and te≈øtified their zeal for us on many occa≈øions.

This I believe was the true ≈øtate of parties the latter end of the year 1781. Happy would it have been for this country if the ≈øervants of the public could have di≈øentangled their minds from the re≈øentments and party-rage which prevail in civil wars! A proclamation then framed upon principles of wi≈ødom and humanity, would have had a happy tendency to bury in oblivion what was pa≈øt; to extingui≈øh from the minds of men, a ≈øen≈øe of late injuries; to unite the affections of all; and re≈øtore the country to order and tranquillity.

The proclamation of September 27th, as I ob≈øerved before, went on the Governor's idea that the great body of the people who had taken protection had thereby forfeited their lives, liberty, and property. He takes upon him to offer pardon to every one of them who ≈øhould join our ≈øtandard in 30 days, and ≈øerve 6 months in the militia, as common ≈øoldiers; excepting from this benefit, tho≈øe who were bani≈øhed the State in the beginning of the troubles; the congratulators, and ≈øuch as held commi≈ø≈øions civil or military on the 27th of September, or were then with the enemy. I ≈øhall ≈øay nothing of the good or bad policy of excluding ≈øuch a number of citizens as this exception comprehended, admitting he had the power he pretended to‚ñ™ However on the 17th of November he i≈ø≈øued a ≈øecond proclamation, extending the benefits held out by the former under the like terms.

As the capture of Cornwallis and his army was known to the Governor when this proclamation came out; as the Briti≈øh troops had ab≈øolutely lo≈øt their courage with their lo≈øs at Eutaw, and the Penn≈øylvania Line was on the march from York-Town to our a≈ø≈øi≈øtance: When this, and the ≈øtate the country was in at that juncture, is con≈øidered; I leave the reader to judge, whether the proclamation was not calculated rather for creating mi≈øchief than for rai≈øing a force. For it laid all who neglected or refu≈øed, not only under a ≈øtigma and reproach, but under ≈øuch di≈øabilities as degraded them below the rank of freemen.

Obliging the whole country that had taken protection to turn out and ≈øerve ≈øix months in the militia, was the greate≈øt oppre≈ø≈øion imaginable; and the contriver of it well knew, as tho≈øe do, who now drive down the mea≈øure, that it was commanding what was ab≈øolutely impo≈ø≈øible. Men are generally ≈øo embarra≈ø≈øed with inconveniences of one ≈øort or another, that there is no ≈øociety on earth, the aggregate body whereof could all quit their families and homes for ≈øix months. In our ca≈øe, not to mention how much agriculture would ≈øuffer by ≈øuch emigration, the heads of tho≈øe families who re≈øided within the enemy's range, were peculiarly circum≈øtanced. They were no doubt called on by the feelings of
fathers, hu≈øbands, or protectors to ≈øtay and afford the feeble protection they could to their families, or avert the di≈øtre≈øs or ruin that would en≈øue; if they joined our army, which at that time had not the power of protecting them.

Ordering them out, therefore, without regard to local ≈øituation, ≈øickne≈øs, or other di≈øtre≈øs, was an extravagant act of power. Whether they re≈øided within or out of the enemy's garri≈øon or guards; whether a man's wife or little ones, or the property the Briti≈øh had left him unplundered, were in or out of the enemy's reach: All this was nothing; they mu≈øt abandon the whole to the rage of an unprincipled, revengeful enemy; and ≈øally forth, like Don Quixote, ≈øetting Briti≈øh guards and parties at defiance, in que≈øt of adventures on the report of a proclamation; and what perhaps was more mortifying; they mu≈øt humble them≈øelves and ≈øupplicate for mercy as criminals, at the feet of a man who a little before was a fellow citizen, no more than on a fooling with them≈øelves.

I conjure any ≈øen≈øible hone≈øt man to tell me, if this was acting the part of a magi≈øtrate, framing regulations for the ea≈øe and convenience of a people, over who≈øe happine≈øs he was appointed to pre≈øide? In the high ≈øtation he was, ought he not to have looked on the people at large as children of the republic; who≈øe only crime was a misfortune that admitted of no alternative? In≈øtead of adding to the li≈øt of their calamities, from Briti≈øh oppre≈ø≈øion, ought he not to have comforted them, and rather to palliate, or cover over any ≈øtain of di≈øhonour, if any there was, than lay them under the condemnation of treachery to their country? this proclamation was like putting the citizens in a Bear-≈økin, and then worrying them; or according to a more ju≈øt compari≈øon made by General Gad≈øden on the Confi≈øcation Bill; he ≈øaid it was like an Auto de fe, a ≈øort of proceeding u≈øed in Portugal again≈øt Heretics, where they are dre≈ø≈øed in frocks painted over with figures of fiends and devils, to excite a horror in the multitude again≈øt them.

div.head: III. On the Mode of conducting the Election for the A≈ø≈øembly at Jack≈øonborough.
div.p: I Shall proceed to examine the mode of conducting the elections in the latter end of 1781, for the A≈ø≈øembly at Jack≈øonborough; as I think it of con≈øequence that the public ≈øhould be acquainted with the nature of it. The Governor re≈øolved to convene the A≈ø≈øembly in January; and whether the mea≈øure of calling them at all, at that time, will turn out a ble≈ø≈øing or a cur≈øe to us, time will di≈øcover. The writs of election were accompanied with printed in≈øtructions to the returning officers, not to admit any per≈øon to vote, but ≈øuch as obeyed his extraordinary proclamation. The returning officers had al≈øo further orders from the Governor to chu≈øe particular men whom he named, and according to ≈øuch nomination they were cho≈øen.
Our Con≈øtitution or Charter or Liberties a≈øcertains the qualification of voters, and ≈øecures this valuable priviledge by the following clau≈øe:

p.q: Every free white man who has attained to the age of 21 years, and hath been a re≈øident and an inhabitant in this State for the ≈øpace of one whole year, and hath freehold of fifty acres of land, or a town lot, and been ≈øeized of it ≈øix months previous to the election, or paid a tax, or was taxable ≈øix months previous to the election in a ≈øum equal to the tax on fifty acres of land, ≈øhall be deemed qualified to vote for, and be eligible, &c.

div.p: Thus the Con≈øtitution gives to every ≈øuch citizen a participation in the Sovereignty of the State, which right and ≈øhare neither Governor nor both Hou≈øes can take away without e≈øtabli≈øhing a tyrannical government on the ruins of our Liberties. And at any rate the A≈ø≈øembly could not alter the Con≈øtitution nor any part of it without ninety days notice by the‚Äî≈øection. For the Governer therefore to a≈ø≈øume authority to deprive ≈øome citizens of this right and give it to others, is a flagrant in≈øtance of tyranny, and is ≈øcarcely to be equalled in any country that pretended to freedom. The priviledge of voting for tho≈øe who are to make laws for us, is a right ≈øo inherent in every citizen of our State, that the Governor or Legi≈ølature, who pretends under any condition or limitation to deprive him of it, and then return it as a matter of favour, actually plays the tyrant by ≈øo doing: It is at once ve≈øting the government in a few independant of the whole: An overt-act to change the nature and form of our Con≈øtitution: Not an injury to one or a few individuals, but I aver it to be what in every Republican Government is called crimen lae≈øae libertatis, high trea≈øon again≈øt the ≈øovereignty and liberties of the people.

It is e≈ø≈øential to the being of a parliament, ≈øays Black≈øtone, that elections ≈øhould be ab≈øolutely free. Therefore all undue influence on the electors is illegal and ≈øtrongly prohibited; Mr. Locke ranks it among tho≈øe breaches of tru≈øt in the executive magi≈øtrate, which according to his notion amount to a di≈ø≈øolution of the government if he employs the force, the trea≈øure and offices of ≈øociety to corrupt the Repre≈øentatives, or openly to pre-engage the electors, and pre≈øcribe what manner of per≈øons ≈øhall be cho≈øen. For thus to regulate candidates and electors and new model the ways of election; what is it, ≈øays he, but to cut up the government by the roots, and poi≈øon the very fountain of public ≈øecurity. Black≈øt. vol. 1. p. 178.

The right of electing tho≈øe who act as public tru≈øtees in the legi≈ølature is by our con≈øtitution ≈øo ve≈øted in the citizen, ≈øo per≈øonal to him, that he cannot ≈øurrender or re≈øign it, any more than the ≈øub≈øtance of his body can part with its ≈øhadow; nor can it be forfeited until he be convicted of ≈øome notorious crime, on a fair trial by his peers. It is indefea≈øible and hereditary, and the Governor with all the authority which an act of A≈ø≈øembly could give him, was only an agent or tru≈øtee, who could no more aboli≈øh
this right of the principal or people who appointed him, than a man who is only attorney or manager of an e≈øtate, can de≈øtroy or alienate the right of his employer. The manager exerci≈øing an act of owner≈øhip, ≈øuch as ≈øelling or converting it to his own emolument, makes void his commi≈ø≈øion. The power of the tru≈øt returns to the owner, and the other is re≈øpon≈øible for his breach of it. So the Governor ≈øeizing on the freedom of election, which alone con≈øtitutes the freedom of the people, was de≈øtroying all legal authority in him≈øelf. Such an act of power was a felo de ≈øe; a murderer of it≈øelf. It was no longer the act of the law, but of the u≈øurper; and packing an A≈ø≈øembly in which he confirmed all his doings, was making the matter ten times wor≈øe; it was employing the forms of parliament, of law and con≈øtitution to rivet his u≈øurpation.

As to the Governor's extraordinary powers in the rece≈øs of the A≈ø≈øembly, to do and execute whatever he thought nece≈ø≈øary for the ≈øafety of the State. On due con≈øideration of this clau≈øe, I believe no lawyer will be ≈øo hardy as to deny, that this power only authori≈øed him to ≈øupport, not to overturn the charter of our liberties and fundamental laws of the State, and by this precedent expo≈øe us in future to all the mi≈øchiefs of arbitrary power.

Encroachments on public liberty commence in all republics with plau≈øible pretences of promoting ≈øome public good, or remedying ≈øome evil. In any government where there is the lea≈øt ≈øpark of freedom, open and barefaced tyranny can never in≈øinuate it≈øelf. It is obliged therefore like the original tempter in Paradi≈øe, to a≈ø≈øume a ≈øhape which may conceal its ≈øubtilty, and the ≈øtory of every nation affords examples of this truth. In the in≈øtance before me, the pretence was "a nece≈ø≈øity for excluding from votes the di≈øaffected or protection-men, to prevent a tory influence in the Legi≈ølature." I look upon this to be a ≈øhallow pretence: It al≈øo amounts to a calumny on the great body of the people, who hated the Briti≈øh government as much, and loved Republican equality much better than ≈øome people I could name I have been told that certain gentlemen frequently make it their bu≈øine≈øs in company, to propagate a notion, that the people of this State are not capable to govern them≈øelves, and that the con≈øtitution ≈øhould be changed into an ari≈øtocracy, or the government of certain potent families. Does not this let the Cat out of the bag, and account for ≈øome late proceedings?. The political ≈øentiments of the public were ≈øuch, and the hatred to the Briti≈øh ≈øo univer≈øal, that had a free, impartial election prevailed, there would have been, not only no danger, but the ≈øettlement of the government, and peace of the country, would in all probability have been con≈øulted much better than it was. I believe as much as I exi≈øt, that it was a great and public misfortune, that the Governor returned to the country, or that Major Hyrne, whom I regard by the by, as a man of great merit, exchanged the Charle≈øtown militia. Had they remained where they were, a convention of the people would have been
held as ≈øoon as things were ripe for it: Elections would have been made agreeable to the con≈øtitution; ≈øomething like temperance and ju≈øtice might have prevailed; and the State at this time might have been in freedom and ≈øerenity; in≈øtead of the arbitrary mea≈øures, the ≈øpirit of faction, and di≈øcontent, ruin and mi≈øery of families, which like a di≈ømal gloomy mi≈øt hangs over the land at pre≈øent.

At any rate we could not have been wor≈øted, for anarchy or no Government is far preferable to an arbitrary one. How different the policy adopted in New-Jer≈øey, and other parts of America, where the enemy for a while domineered, and the people uniformly took a temporary protection! Not one of them affords an example of a public ≈øervant fixing on the tyranny exerci≈øed by the enemy over his countrymen, as a ma≈øk or pretence for accu≈øing them of di≈øaffection, and taking the government out of their hands. Not one of them trampled, as we have done, on the charter of their liberties or con≈øtitution, under colour of guarding again≈øt tory influence.

This influence the State of Jer≈øey apprehended a few months ago; but what did they do? Not to open a theatre for the citizens to worry and per≈øecute each other, under di≈øtinctions of the virtuous few, and protection-men; they only pa≈ø≈øed an act ≈øub≈øtituting the mode of giving in their votes at the elections, openly and publicly, in≈øtead of balloting as formerly.

How the legi≈ølature could make this proclamation of the Governor the ground-work of all their proceedings, cannot be accounted for, but by con≈øidering that ≈øuch was his influence, and the management of his party, that it became dangerous to make any oppo≈øition. The great majority of the A≈ø≈øembly were men who had taken protection; but who from local ≈øituation were enabled to join the army, or find a ≈øub≈øtitute.

What a ≈øtrong impre≈ø≈øion of horror of the Governor's arbitrary power mu≈øt tho≈øe members have upon them, when they gave their votes for degrading their fellow-citizens from the rights of freemen, only for doing what they did them≈øelves, making a temporary ≈øubmi≈ø≈øion to a conqueror! Some gratified the workings of revenge, and others ≈øome other paltry pa≈ø≈øion. But they were all mere tools to carry on the bu≈øine≈øs of u≈øurpation on the freedom of their country, and rai≈øe a few families to a height of power as would one day cru≈øh them and their po≈øterity.

div.head: IV. On the Exclu≈øion Act, which cuts of the Citizens from the Rights of Election.

p.hi: The following words of the preamble of the Exclu≈øion Act are worth quoting:

p.q:
AND WHEREAS it is incon≈øi≈øtent with ju≈øtice and policy that any of the per≈øons who are excluded by the Governor's
proclamation from pardon ≈øhould be admitted to vote for, or be eligible as members of the Legi≈ølature; be it enacted, that no per≈øon by the ≈øaid proclamation excepted, ≈øhall be entitled to vote for, or be eligible as members of either branch of the Legi≈ølature.

div.p: This Act of A≈ø≈øembly ≈øuppo≈øes with the Governor, that all who did not come in whithin the time ≈øpecified by the proclamation, and ≈øerve ≈øix months, had forfeited their liberty, and that ≈øuch as obeyed, were re≈øtored to lo≈øt freedom. But the gentlemen of both Hou≈øes forgot, that the citizens of South-Carolina had to thank the Governor for nothing: Their rights and liberties were founded on ≈øomething el≈øe be≈øides parchment, or paper, or a proclamation; they were built on the laws of nature, and the fundamental laws of the State, and they were ≈øupported by the valour, and cemented by the blood of tho≈øe brave men who fought, bled, and died in the cau≈øe of freedom, not for the u≈øurpation of a few, but for the liberties and happine≈øs of all. And yet this wretched country at this very hour, when peace and happine≈øs ≈øhould prevail, is ≈øplit into a faction of two cla≈ø≈øes of men; the one ≈øort, a ≈øet of mongrel freemen, begot between G‚ÄîR‚Äîand a proclamation, or his party in the A≈ø≈øembly; or holding the privilege of voting becau≈øe they could advance fifty or ≈øixty guineas to procure a ≈øub≈øtitute. The re≈øt are aliens in the government, dive≈øted of every privilege we have been contending for the≈øe ≈øeven years pa≈øt, and to be ruled and taxed without their con≈øent. Even the unfortunate citizens of Charle≈øtown, who tho' they were not ≈øix months-men under G‚Äî R‚Äî's proclamation, yet were actually ≈øix years-men like common ≈øoldiers, before the reduction of the town. Their zeal for the cau≈øe, and courage in ≈øupporting it, was often proved on dangerous and honourable trials: They were all taken in defending it; and the great bulk of them bore hunger, in≈øults and per≈øecution before they would ≈øubmit even to a conqueror; yet are their ≈øervices not only forgotten, but they have been abu≈øed and worried as if they were convicts, and are now little better than va≈ø≈øals in their own city, except a few of the richer ≈øort, who could buy the freedom of voting; which it ≈øeems before this la≈øt general election was let to ≈øale as it were with an OYEZ. Gold, it appears, with all their pretended fears of tory influence can work a miracle, by making a man a whig, and buy a right of voting or being elected. Is not this like the coming of the day of judgment to our freedom? when the right of election, to keep which cha≈øte and un≈øpotted, we went to war with Great Britain, is now, like a public ≈øtrumpet, to be embraced only by him who can pull out his guineas, and advance a mercenary reward?

I have now done with the proclamation and election bu≈øine≈øs; and here I mu≈øt declare, that I can lay my hand on my heart, and ≈øay, that I entertain no per≈øonal di≈ølike or prejudice to J‚Äî R‚Äî. It is not the man I cen≈øure but the mea≈øure. Probably any other citizen with the power of doing what he plea≈øed, would
have acted no better; for ≈øupreme authority is ≈øo intoxicating to human nature, that even the good are mi≈øled by it. The aggrandi≈øement of his family, and perpetuating power in it; or being at the head of an ari≈øtocracy, is of far greater con≈øequence to an able, ambitious man, than public freedom. div.head: V. On the Confi≈øcation Act.
div.p: I SHALL now enter on the Confi≈øcation Act; make a few remarks on the Amercement Law; and conclude with endeavouring to prove that an Act of Amne≈øty and Oblivion is the only means for re≈øtoring order, tranquility and happine≈øs to our common country.
The principal difficulty I meet with on a ≈øubject where ≈øo much may be ≈øaid, is to confine my≈øelf within the narrow compa≈øs I propo≈øed.

It is impo≈ø≈øible not to feel di≈øtre≈øs when we reflect on the mi≈øeries which each party in a civil war, inflicts on the other as they become uppermo≈øt. The cruel oppre≈ø≈øions of the Briti≈øh, particularly the per≈øonal in≈øults and outrage we ≈øuffered from their officers, after the fall of the country, is enough to make a man ≈øhudder.

Their treatment was ≈øo extravagantly outrageous, that no de≈øcription will ever give a ju≈øt idea of it; and to my≈øelf who was a witne≈øs and a ≈øufferer, it appears like a dream, and almo≈øt incredible to me.
